title: Are websites where you pay someone to write your essay illegal? - Quora

response.answer_text: For the most part, they are not illegal, although there have been some cases of copyright infringement and plagiarism, which can be illegal. So the sites themselves, no, the content they product, perhaps. Since they do not publish the content online, and instead bill themselves as merely “marketplaces”, they would likely not be illegal, per se.  I think the bigger question, however, is “Who uses these sites, and for what purpose?” The answers to these two questions are nearly invariably: Who — studentsFor what purpose — academic fraudNow academic fraud also may not be illegal in your jurisdiction… but it’s usually career suicide if it is ever, ever found out. This is true, even if you don’t land in academia, if you use your academic credential which was fraudulently earned in order to obtain employment. Even if not criminally charged, the degree may be revoked/rescinded: Revoking Degrees: How and Why Schools Do It - Plagiarism Today Even without plagiarism, someone else taking your tests, writing your essays, etc. — the degree was fraudulently obtained. If you then went on to obtain a position, within academia or without, a revoked degree means that your position was now fraudulently obtained. That can easily result in civil and criminal penalties, especially if you end up as a CEO of a company, and therefore failed in your fiduciary responsibility, and defrauded stockholders. The SEC does not take kindly to that sort of thing. It gets worse if it was an MD or JD or other organization where admission to practice is based not only on ability, but also upon the degree.  Personally, I’d say just learn to write, and call it a day. Avoid these sites like you’d avoid wearing a Pepe the Frog, Osama bin Laden, or Al Franken T-shirt.

Depending on the legislation around your way, they may or may not be illegal. What they’ll invariably be, though, is dishonest, and this is true in a couple of ways: “Original” essays: The odds of anything produced on such a site actually being original are very poor. Judging by the turnaround times the various shill accounts here and elsewhere spruik, there’s simply no time for someone to do the proper amount of research, planning, drafting, and editing required. The essays will almost certainly be recycled.“No plagiarism, guaranteed!”: Most sites seem to claim this. It’s not true. The essay may have been assembled from a collection of sources and each one cited correctly (unlikely, see above), but that’s not all that plagiarism is. Unless your university or school operates in a very strange way, there’ll be a declaration you’re asked to sign saying “This is my own work”. Doing that when it isn’t your own work makes you guilty of plagiarism when it’s detected. And it will be.

Not currently, but in Australia legislation has recently been drafted which, if passed, will make these illegal and punishable with up to two years imprisonment: Stamping out cheating at Universities. While it is not yet illegal to advertise these services, students who use these sites are in breach of ethical rules at their universities and can receive punishments up to and including exclusion from the university.
